common_errors.cause: Wrong password, user doesn't exist, or wrong host
common_errors.solution: Check password. Verify user exists: SELECT user,host FROM mysql.user; Check host matches.

common_errors.error_pattern: ERROR 2002.*Can't connect to local MySQL server
common_errors.cause: MySQL server not running or socket file wrong
common_errors.solution: Start server: sudo systemctl start mysql. Or use -h 127.0.0.1 for TCP instead of socket.

common_errors.cause: Server not running, firewall blocking, or wrong host/port
common_errors.solution: Verify server running. Check port (default 3306). Check firewall rules.
List databases: SHOW DATABASES; Create: CREATE DATABASE dbname;

common_errors.cause: User lacks privileges on this database
common_errors.solution: Grant access: GRANT ALL ON dbname.* TO 'user'@'host';
Check query syntax. Common: reserved words as identifiers (use backticks), missing quotes.

common_errors.cause: User lacks specific privilege (SELECT, INSERT, etc.)
common_errors.solution: Grant needed privilege: GRANT SELECT ON db.table TO 'user'@'host';

common_errors.cause: Connection dropped - timeout, server crash, or network issue
common_errors.solution: Check server status. Increase wait_timeout. Check network stability.
Use -p flag to prompt for password: mysql -u user -p
Use sudo: sudo mysql. Or change auth: ALTER USER 'root'@'localhost' IDENTIFIED WITH mysql_native_password BY 'pass';
